job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Berkeley, CA
pros: Berkeley is one of the richest and deepest universities in the world (it's top 5 in almost everything), and is the ideal place for grad school. Nuff said.
cons: It's grad school; you have to work long hours all the time, become obsessed with your work. Compensation is enough to live on but expect not to save anything. Professors can be hit or miss; some are wonderful people, others work their students and postdocs to the bone.

pros:
The location -- the Bay Area.
The broad array of top expertise.
cons:
The compensation is lower than in private universities that are as prestigious.
The bureaucracy is extreme -- and I say this as someone who studies organizations.
There is a "bleed blue" culture that demands faculty give their all through service to the campus, even if that takes away from research.

pros: Amazing culture, beautiful location. Supportive management. Brilliant colleagues. Fun peers. Great experience, I really wish the economy allowed for me to apply to be hired on staff full-time.
cons: Expensive area in which to live. Traffic crossing the bridge can be obnoxious if you want to live in the city of San Francisco.

review_title: A wonderful place to work with equally amazing staff.
job_title: Administrative Student Assistant in San Jose, CA
pros: Amazing and caring management and staff. Very pleasant work experience and environment. Leadership is very helpful and approachable. Bosses are super sweet and down to earth.
cons: A lot of mail during the beginning of the year. Lots of monkey work, other words repetitive work. Sometimes have to deal with annoying and persistent students.

pros: Great name brand and decent benefits.  They have a postdoctoral union now, that helps keep things fair for postdocs. They have a lot of resources for postdocs in terms of job hunting and groups.
cons: The pay is lower for postdocs than at most other bay area universities. Also you will be a postdoctoral researcher, which is it's own con.

pros: Great facilities and access to additional resources at nearby LBL. A great seminar series and lots of news ideas.
cons: Everything starts ten minutes late on "Berkeley time". Although all of the graduate students are bright and capable, not all are highly motivated. The level of intensity is lower than at places like Caltech.

review_title: Academic Center Assistant. It's a good school and employer.
job_title: Academic Center Assistant in Berkeley, CA
pros: They're willing to work with your schedule as a student, and provide training. Work study available. As an ACA the work is easy and you can spend time doing homework or online sometimes.
cons: Pay is usually on the low end, for student jobs anyway. They don't let students work more than 20 hours per week. Not much potential for advancement in this role.

review_title: Great place for a work-study student! - UC Berkeley
job_title: Workstudy Student-Worker At Pacific Film Archive Library in Berkeley, CA
pros: Everyone at the Pacific Film Archive was a joy to work with. They were all very friendly and approachable, and my manager was flexible with my academic schedule. I learned a lot and it gave me insight into film curating and programming.
cons: The work was sometimes tedious, as you would consistently do the same work.

job_title: RSF Customer Service Representative in Berkeley, CA
pros: While working at the RSF, I am allowed very flexible hours in a friendly work environment. The 3 hour shifts allow my time to be spread out in between classes.
cons: The pay is somewhat low, and there are sometimes some moody patrons, but that can be said about many service jobs.

job_title: Program Coordinator in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Great connections to other faculty, students, professionals across campus and outside campus. Made some really good friends and some really good working experience.
cons: Bureaucracy can be a slight irritant at times. However, it depends on the department and your supervisor as well.  Building good personal connections with staff helps as well to address delays and other challenges.

job_title: Staff Research Associate III in Berkeley, CA
pros: Being an academic researcher has its plusses. The schedule is flexible and the benefits are great.
cons: The layoffs in all the support areas means I now spend a lot of time doing things that aren't my job because there simply isn't anyone else willing to do it. Dealing with HR and purchasing is always frustrating and the buildings are filthy and run down because no money is put into upkeep. Compensation is low but benefits are good.

pros: I have been working here for the last 4 years in the Video Technology Department for the Cal Football Department. This experience has truly been amazing! I've had the pleasure of cultivating relationships with such sincere, open-minded, tenacious, and hard-working individuals.
cons: HOLIDAYS DON'T EXIST IN FOOTBALL!

job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Berkeley, CA
pros: Since I teach, it's doing something good for the world.
cons: Seems like the budget they operate with is limited, and it shows up in aspects like office space. The salaries for student instructors are on the low side for living in the bay area.

review_title: Chill job, but you don't do or learn much as a student employee
job_title: IS&T DOCS Technician in Berkeley, CA
pros: The work environment is very chill. No harsh deadlines and supervisors are always very accommodating toward students' schedules. Hours are also very flexible.
cons: As a student employee, I expected to learn a lot about IT, work with customers, gradually gain experience and greater responsibilities. Instead, I've been doing the same mundane tasks for the last 9 months, and frankly, I do barely anything and still get paid.

pros: Management was very good, reasonable and clear in their expectations. As I was a student, they were very flexible with the hours and the pay was better than most part-time in hospitality or retail, the usual alternatives.
cons: At least in my department, there was really no room for growth or much of any advancement. The work itself was repetitive and not particularly interesting. Also because of the budget issues funding for my position was very tenuous.

pros: The ranked number 1 public university in the US, and a top tier 1 university in the US. Amazing colleagues and students. Fantastic location, and ecosystem.
cons: There is no con to working at UC Berkeley, working there is a privilege I am greatly honored to have. It is a fantastic place.

job_title: Junior Consultant in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: It's a great school job to hold since they are very understanding but still expect a high level of professionalism. They train up students to different computer skills and also allow students to seek promotions. Give students a chance to practice leadership and develop professional skillsets.
cons: The pay is low compared to other places but I think this place makes it up through the opportunities for advancement.

review_title: Working in Higher Education is Awesome!
job_title: Cal Student Orientation Counselor in Berkeley, CA
pros: Working in higher education is so rewarding. The work is always changing and there is constantly new. There is always room to learn and grow.
cons: This is an environment of change and while some change is good, some of it has been difficult to understand and deal with.

pros:
learned how to deal with all sorts of people on the phone
negotiation skills-- convincing alumni to donate
fun work environment with games and music
cons:
hard to get promoted to the next level
had to deal with angry people on the phone
difficult to get donations

review_title: satisfaction depends on department and boss
job_title: Senior Human Resources Generalist in Berkeley, CA
pros: Great mission, smart people, I work with a good team, have a wonderful boss, benefits are good.
cons: Salary is low, decisions take forever, too much middle management.  Little money put into employee used systems enhancements.

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Berkeley, CA
pros: Was good to be in the college atmosphere, access to libraries, online tools, campus events.
cons: Very isolated, everyone seems overwhelmed with the amount of work they have to do. Budget cuts mean everyone is doing the job of 3+ people. Add to that the bureaucracy that means inefficient use of time/resources anyway... and, well, not much gets done.

job_title: Postdoctoral Employee in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Here you would find great research atmosphere, great scientists and the best people. You can easily communicate and discuss about your research with all kinds of great people.
cons: The benefit for the Postdoc is not the best in the area, but the union for the UC postdoc is trying to improve it or at least keep it not getting worse.

pros: Beautiful Location, easy commute, regular breaks, closed for winter break. Compensated well when working on holidays. Great and fair boss.
cons: When you work 1000 hours as a temp, you are supposed to get your status switched to full university employee. The upper administration tried to weasle its way out of giving that to me. Luckily my manager was able to show proof and get that for me. It doesn't feel right though when the management isn't on your side.

pros: Very enthusiastic and intelligent coworkers. Always something to do and a new problem to solve. Everyone was genuinely interested in solving the problems.
cons: The amount of work was sometimes overwhelming. I was also a student at the same time so it was sometimes hard to balance the aspects of work life and student life.

job_title: Senior Business Architect in Berkeley, CA
pros: Interesting technology supporting researchers.  You get a pension once you've been there 5 years.
cons: This is the 3rd year of layoffs.  The more time you have had with them the  more protected from being laid off.  I think this is insane.    The culture is very insular,

review_title: Lots of flexibility, great coworkers and management, and lots to learn.
job_title: ETS Student Staff in Berkeley, CA
pros: Learn how to balance work and school. They were very understanding of my personal life + school life, and allowed time off during critical periods. The pay was decent and the people were very friendly.
cons: There were strict schedules and finding shifts that work for you was sometimes challenging. It does become an occasional battle to stay awake during certain shifts when you've already learned everything..

review_title: Great place to work, ideal environment
pros: It's great to work on the cutting edge with some of the top researchers in the world with a good amount of resources with which to conduct research.  The university environment is quite nice and brings in many potential collaborators.
cons: Academic pay is low compared to industry.  Sometimes there are campus politics to deal with and government funded research depends on continued support from the government.

pros: Great work environment, great students. Training is done first for new counselors where they can attend academic advising sessions with the students and experienced counselor to gain experience.
cons: Work can get too hectic and overwhelming with the amount of work thrown at you during the regular semesters.

pros: I'm here only part time for a few months, yet they have given me benefits!  AMAZING.  I feel like a proper full time contracted staff member, not a temp.
cons: So far I can't see any - the benefits are basic, but that's fine because I'm part-time, but I'm grateful for the benefits.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Excellent and supportive learning environment. Wonderful mentor-ship, and knowledgeable, friendly colleges. Lab space very safe and clean. Necessary supplies always available.
cons: Lack of attention from upper-management. Rarely was able to make and find appointments with PI. General lack of feedback on performance, and guidance sometimes lacking.

review_title: Awesome school, great students, amazing experience
job_title: Senior Programmer in San Francisco, CA
pros: I loved working on campus and enjoying the campus life but being paid. The schedule was relaxed. Worked 9-5 most weeks, never on the weekend. Office of Admissions is very supportive of work life balance.
cons: You gotta pay to park for work around the school. It's also not very accessible by freeway and commuting into Berkeley is a pain. The salary is under what you would make in the private sector.

review_title: Great Company with Flexible Hours and Well-Trained Managers
job_title: Concierge Desk Attendant in Berkeley, CA
pros: They create great opportunities for students to move up the "foodchain," with student supervisor roles and pay raises. They also offer flexible hours which is important for part-time employees.
cons: Not really any cons from my experience. Just that I felt like it was sort of high stakes for a student role. Felt really bad when I had emergencies and couldn't make shifts.

review_title: UC Berkeley is a wonderful place to work where employees share a commitment to excellence in higher education
pros: commitment to higher education in staff and faculty,  very diverse and multicultural institution, excellent benefits and opportunities for growth and professional development
cons: salaries are often lower than in the competitive marketplace because it is a state institution, there is often a lot of bureaucracy, budget cuts can make it an unstable work environment

review_title: Teaching bright students in world renowned institution is priceless
job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Berkeley, CA
pros:
- the students are amazing
- a lot of freedom in re-adjusting teaching assignment with other GSIs
- a lot of resources are available for GSIs to improve on their teaching
cons:
- the professors may not be in top of their game
- the pay is low but it is made up by tuition remission
- the promotional growth is limited and performance is internal

review_title: Dismal treatment of staff, no upward growth, low pay
pros: Obviously having a State job allows one to have great benefits.
cons: The supervisors/leadership is below standards. People in power positions do not heed the concerns of their staff. Many are underqualified to even be in a position of power. When you complain about management you are often subject to retaliation and ridicule.

job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Berkeley, CA
pros: Only part time work, so flexible schedule and hours.  Includes decent benefits: health insurance, dental, and vision.  Great for people who enjoy teaching.
cons: Pay is low for the Bay Area and is definitely not a living wage.  Does not provide a full fee remission for graduate student fees.

review_title: I had a great teaching experience at Berkeley.
pros: There is an interesting mix of areas of expertise and skills that made it a comepelling place to learn and to study concurrently.
cons: It is a public university and some departments suffer for lack of funding and resource. Other than that it really does bring a good mix of unique minds into play.

pros: Meet a lot of people with different backgrounds.  I had a very flexible work schedule so I was able to accommodate all of my school activities.
cons: The pay isn't that great and it was a part time gig so I didn't expect a whole lot.

review_title: Public University is a Double Edge Sword
pros: The best and the brightest come here and allow for a thriving work environment. People are regularly helpful and the atmosphere around campus is near unbeatable.
cons: Public university means funding and pay is limited, and as such, can be troublesome at times. Politics becomes a huge issue here, especially with tenure track.

pros: Keeps you busy if you are someone who is afraid of not working. Tasks are not very hard. Co-workers are generally very nice and personal. Work with students. Good benefits considering that it is a public university.
cons: Some tasks are menial and, a specially if you are doing administration. Average pay.

pros: The resources at Cal are amazing! The people are smart, and most people are supportive of you development.
cons: There is a bit of an "Ivory tower" feeling to Cal. If you are not in the in crowd, it can be lonely. Open-mindedness is surprisingly low for what I expected from Berkeley. The pay is low.

pros: UC Berkeley offers a very generous benefits package including one of the best available health care plans, pension and 403(b) and 457 plans. Sufficient vacation and sick leave.
cons: Gradually increasing contribution to pension plan over the last years lowered the already lower salaries for many employers without major salary adjustments due to inflation.

pros: Great working environment, beautiful campus, engaged and intelligent students. The experience of teaching itself at Berkeley is quite rewarding.
cons: Very difficult HR and paperwork processes. Things often take quite a while to get approved and move forward. Can cause delays or even errors in payroll. Most of the problems I faced were bureaucratic in nature.

job_title: Mail Room Clerk in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Pretty good job for a full-time student who just needs some extra cash. Super easy job, minimal supervision, plenty of downtime to get your homework done.
cons: A little too much downtime sometimes, the job can be pretty boring. No raises and definitely no room to grow.

job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Berkeley, CA
pros: Students as a whole are appreciative of GSI's especially in such a large school where it's harder for students to have access to professors.
cons:
Workload and experiences vary wildly between departments and professor teaching the class, as might be expected. Graduate students should shop around and ask others for advice about specific GSI roles.

No central location to search for GSI opportunities, so graduate students have to dig around a lot to find suitable positions.

job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Berkeley, CA
pros: For the most part, great faculty and great students (engaged, interested in the material - minus the few obnovious pre-meds). A culture invested in learning and exchanging ideas. Very high academic standards, which was a pleasure to teach.
cons: Sprawling bureaucracy, many incompetent employees with frequent mistakes - for examples, I did not get paid on time no less than 3 times in 2.5 years and had to contact many people to figure out the problem.

pros:
Gain a LOT of customer service experience.
Good pay, doesn't have to be work study.
cons:
it's pretty boring.
they take your bonus away if you don't have enough rejections in a day.
I once got a $100 bonus down to $20 because i didn't lie like everyone else and give false rejections.

pros: UC Berkeley has some of the best minds int he world
cons: the university itself is divided between the ever-increasing corporate bureaucracy and instructors/students. it's being strangled by budget mismanagement, and everything always feels like it's one piece of tape away from not working.

pros: Worked with great people, students and teachers. Got a great hourly salary through work-study. Regular set schedules and training beforehand.
cons: Some communication issues from higher-ups. Sometimes there were technical difficulties that we were not trained for, and just thrown off the deep end to resolve. Hard to find the right people to contact about paperwork and problems to resolve.

review_title: A great place to do research and learn, but typical public university bureaucracy
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Top quality colleagues and facilities; respectful and knowledgeable department leaders; great benefits.
cons: UCB suffers from the typical large public university bureaucracy.  If you have a work-related issue that requires going outside of your department, it can be quite an ordeal.  Also funding is contingent on the UC Board of Regents, which can be stressful and is out of anyone's power.

review_title: Exciting Research in an overpriced, weird America
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Berkeley, CA
pros:
Research is great at UC Berkeley. 
Working with great indivduals who are also, not from Berkeley, CA
cons:
Being in Berkeley means you are close to SF, so housing prices are extremely high. 
Pay isn't great, you will be belowing nearly your entire paycheck on rent. 
Lack of cheap, decent food around campus. 
Expect to pay $9 for meals which you could get for $5-6 in the mid west

review_title: The admissions committee is a great group to work with - this position is a good part time role with flexible schedule
pros: I love how flexible this job is - I can work anytime, the head of the team really cares about making the job more enjoyable and efficient
cons: Because most of the job is done from home, the lack of interaction with other team members on a daily basis could be hard at times

review_title: Good for people, bad for bureaucracy and waste
job_title: Computer Programmer in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Great people, stimulating environment, beautiful campus, culture/food in Berkeley
cons: Salary not competitive with other tech salaries in Bay Area, bureaucracy, politics, many "lifers" just riding it out so they can collect their pension takes away from work ethic and morale

job_title: Graduate Academic Advisor in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: UC Berkeley has a supportive culture, realistic and useful employee protections, and a fair wage/salary system as a public/state institution.
cons: The bureaucracy is real! There are redundancies and layers of people to work with in order to get some of the simpler things done in the name of standardization. Good intentions, sometimes incredibly frustrating.

review_title: Great opportunity to learn and interact with fantastic minds
pros: Having a PhD from Berkeley not only gives you the prestige. It is located strategically next to biotech companies, surrounded by entrepreneurs, startups and brilliant minds. There are plenty of career development workshops that make it an excellent place for preparing you for your next big step.
cons: There are too many things to do and you don't have enough time to do them all.

pros: Comfortable environment of peers and senior staff who are there to mentor you and help you grow as opposed to breathing down your neck.
cons: Some teams operate better than others... as in all work place environments. However, I think the staff could do a bit more to help better distribute talent, resources, and mentorship.

review_title: I've had a good time working part-time as a student.
pros: Because they understand that I'm still a full-time student, my work schedule has been quite flexible.  The compensation is not bad and I've been able to gain valuable teaching experience.
cons: The actual paperwork/management/initial scheduling is a bit unorganized and finalized last minute for the departments that I worked under.

review_title: Great learning opportunity as part-time lecturer
pros: Good teaching support and resources available.  Given latitude to develop course and teaching style.  Motivated students.
cons: Some bureaucracy, as to be expected in a large institution.  No parking benefits, so had to feed meter on teaching days.  Not a lot of overt collegiality with others in department due to individual schedules and sabbatical leaves.

review_title: Teaching at UC Berkeley  was deeply engaging and satisfying.
job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Berkeley, CA
pros: Interesting mix of professors, students, researchers. Coursework was challenging and required students and teachers to consider current events and future trends.
cons: As in any institution, there is a lot of bureaucracy involved in doing anything outside of protocol. The course management systems were disjointed and confusing at times. Lots of busy work grading.

pros: The work is easy and staff are friendly. It's a very laid back environment. You just need to know basic computer and office skills.
cons: Professors and Grad students make work very difficult sometimes... even nightmare-ish. The job grades and clocking in and out is not cool.

job_title: Staff Research Associate in Rancho Cordova, CA
pros: There are so many opportunities available to you at Berkeley both in house and through collaborations, and you'll meet some of the brightest and most inspiring people. There sincerely is a culture of growth here, and if you put in the effort and the work, you will find yourself better for it.
cons: The hours can sometimes be hard to manage and it is common to be overwhelmed or stressed.

review_title: Cal Alumni Association- Toxic Work Environment
job_title: Program Manager in San Mateo, CA
pros: Beautiful campus, surrounded by amazing students and faculty, lots of great energy cultivated by students and lots of innovation in the proximity. You get to interact with some great alumni and a lot of the staff is great.
cons: This organization tolerates a level of toxicity that I have never seen in any other organization. Secrecy is how things are run and senior management and HR do not respond to serious concerns like harassment reports. They tolerate emotional abuse, condone discrimination and bias and senior management are professional gaslighters. The organization is run by someone who is very old school and believes that people are only working if they are at their desk. Senior management, especially the Chief Program Officer and Executive Director, completely obfuscate any responsibility in anything that happens in the organization. They do not support staff, they victim blame, and they encourage you to be okay with abusive behavior. There is absolutely no onboarding process, and over the time I have been there, 3 years, no onboarding process has been developed. They do not train managers how to manage because they don’t know how to manage.

pros: Great research is completed here. Great vacation & sick package. You can gain a lot of experience working a job with many hats.
cons: Staff are underappreciated, low paying university, most staff know more than supervisors, everything is politics, low pay, and rude supervisors full of drama. Work has become even more demanding, short staff, room for growth is not as easy as it used to be.

pros: Fantastic mission - educating our future, practicing equity and inclusion. Lot's of opportunity to make improvements.
cons: Challenging to work in such a distributed environment. Takes a long time to get things to happen.

review_title: An excellent student job, but lots of bureaucracy.
pros: You are part of an elite institution and may have opportunities to interact with some of the brightest minds in their field.
cons: There is a lot of floundering around in upper management and when they do re-set their metrics, they are often empty promises.

pros: UC Berkeley is a great place to network. It allows one to be free and find oneself, especially all the undergrad students, while having first class resources at hands reach.
cons: Public university that seems to be alternating to a soon to be private university. Very competitive, a doggy dog world before the real world.

job_title: Software Engineer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: This is a world-class school, everywhere you go you meet bright people.
cons: Ages behind the times as far as technology is concerned.   IT leadership hasn't yet heard about the internet.  The only career opportunities in software engineering are in maintenance of old systems, or implementation of new systems that use obsolete technologies or concepts.

review_title: Great place to be a graduate student
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: An excellent place to work and study; Colleagues are both smart and helpful. Academic environment is open, leading to collaborations.
cons: Main issue is red tape; can take awhile to get administrative things done. Luckily this rarely is a problem, as most of the time is spent in lab.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Worked with a great team that was very dedicated to the work.  You can see how excited people are to come in but this is very dependent on the group you are with.  I may have just gotten lucky
cons: As expected with such a big institution, there is a lot of bureaucracy so you have to take initiative otherwise things can fall through the cracks

job_title: Anonymous Employee in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: I'm constantly learning how to better my skills and apply theoretical principles to tangible applications.
cons: The only potential "downside" to being a student is that I am not making a salary, so I am still dependent on Financial Aid and my parents.

job_title: Undergraduate Financial Aid Counselor in Berkeley, CA
pros: It has its ups and downs, especially with cash flow, but the university consistently does what they can to keep it's staff happy. Excellent co workers all round
cons: Hard to get increases in pay, and moving up in the company really only happens if someone retires, so you have to plan the long term game to works here

review_title: Great opportunity, provided you can afford it
job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Berkeley, CA
pros: Engaged, motivated students; considerable autonomy (depending on appointment); great healthcare and medical facilities (Tang, UC Berkeley Optometry)
cons: Exploitative salary, over-enrolled classes, no intrinsic separation between work and life

review_title: What a wonderful place where we can explore the frontiers of science.
job_title: Assistant Research Scientist in Berkeley, CA
pros: Some of the smartest people I've ever met. Decently well run as a university. How well run a group is depends on the PI.
cons: Funding is always uncertain and messy. Takes a long time to "figure out the system." Low pay compared to industry. Advancement is ... messy. Oh well, welcome to academia!

pros:
Plenty of resources for workers
Working with industry-leading scholars
cons:
Unless you are the principal researcher, it's not somewhere to stay forever. 
Budget cuts

review_title: Excellent research, but postdoc level pay
pros: World class research (I'm in neuroscience), excellent location.  In the past few years Berkeley has taken "alternative" careers more seriously for STEM researchers and now offers many workshops to help people looking beyond the academic track.
cons: Postdoc pay lags Stanford (but hey, you're a postdoc).  Postdocs are basically on the NIH pay scale.  Also, Berkeley's academic disciplines can be a little siloed.

job_title: Academic Service Assistant in Berkeley, CA
pros: Relaxed job with task that are very easily accomplishable. You will be able to do homework on the job if nothing else is going on.
cons: As college students we are being gouged for money by the university in terms of tuition. The least they could do is pay a better wage. It starts at 9.50 an hour; you will be paid 10:00 after 4 hours of work after 5pm.

review_title: Berkeley Law - Great Place for Student Employees

- Career counselors were approachable and friendly

job_title: IT Program Manager in Berkeley, CA

good people to work with

Good IT Community

pros: Great minds in the California PATH research program, very good environment, a good deal for me to experience research before possibly applying for a PhD position. A lot of freedom to learn in different programming areas.
cons: The salary of a temporary position (less than one year) assistant specialist step 1 is twice or three times less than the one I could expect in the Silicon Valley.

review_title: Great place to work if you're OK with complacent co-workers.
job_title: Information Technology in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Great School. Beautiful campus. Good benefits. Nice people. Overall a pretty good place to come to work every day.
cons: A lot of red tape. Hard to be motivated/ambitious and succeed. Huge disparity in pay between some departments/disciplines.

pros: The attorneys and law professors are really nice and helpful. Everyone here is kind and willing to help you connect with other law folks. My supervisor is great, warm and friendly and really makes sure that all the student assistants are well taken cared of.
cons: There are no downside aside from the fact that I'm not sure if they hire students who are not on work-study.

pros: Lots of smart people to learn from. Amazing campus and library. There are plenty of possibilities for collaborations within and between various departments.
cons: Too many people that think they are the smartest and the best. Lots of ego to deal with. As with many university labs, some professors are untouchable. They know it and use it.

pros: UC Berkeley has world-class research and resources, excellent students, fantastic colleagues, and a beautiful and friendly campus.  It is easy to access by bicycle or public transportation.
cons: Working at this top tier institution tends to mean a fast-paced and high stress environment.  Work-life balance is possible, but highly dependent on funding sources.  Job security can also be an issue, especially in a postdoctoral appointment.

review_title: Pockets of great groups to work with!
pros: Stability, very prestigious university - well regarded globally, interfacing with students from every country, majority of colleagues are good people, enjoy working with very smart students and very smart faculty, the benefits package available to employees are quite good.
cons: Pay is usually below market rates. Only real downside....

pros: clear guidelines, good management team. Excellent benefits and pay, if you know to negotiate it up front. wonderful administrative team knows how to deal with the manic higher ups. Excellent work/life balance.
cons: swamped in regulations and red tape since it is a state run organization. Smarmy Cal Berkeley grads run the place and play favorites with each other.

job_title: Research Administrator III in UC Berkeley, CA
pros: Cutting edge research, work can be as interesting and challenging as you choose to make it
cons: Shared Services staff often treated like second class citizens; campus financial functions divided into silos would be helpful to see holisitic implications of systems--no one person seems to know what they are.

job_title: Associate Director of Development in Berkeley, CA
pros: #1 Public University in the world, its public mission of providing access to education; cutting-edge research facility; recognized around the globe; high-achieving students who want to make the world a better place (and most do)
cons: does not pay market rate; little opportunity for promotional growth, especially at the higher-paid positions

job_title: Lead Desktop Administrator in Berkeley, CA
pros: ResComp is a great work environment for students! They offer a lot of leadership and development opportunities and give students a place to learn concrete skill to join the work force!
cons: The responsibilities in DA position have been reduced over the years so it can be challenging to find ways to create value on  day to day basis.

A postdoc has done already such insane efforts in his/her MSc/PhD period and it is improper to push postdocs to work >60 hours/week in a mandatory way to meet the expected performance (including mandatory works in weekends). A postdoc is a short term appointment to do research, publish a few papers and in parallel, perform a professional career development tasks including fellowship programs, referee for journals and conference committees and contribute in external research funding. This short term career development cannot be organized properly if pushing >60 hours/week to do only research. This school is an improper place for doing postdoc but excellent for doing undergraduate/graduate studies. In addition, it is not recommended to work for young advisers as a postdoc at UC Berkeley. Sometimes, they can simply impose conflict of interest or competence to postdocs and the school does not have proper platforms to provide professional solutions to help postdocs to develop their short term career properly and at least, join another group. The university staff (advisers, organizers, etc.) do not have proper leadership and organization skills. They require to attend several workshops to gain skills and experiences on proper project organization, management and handling basic conflicts in the work area. If looking for a place to develop an excellent academic postdoc in the Bay area without observing such organization troubles, it might be better to consider Stanford University.
